pageContext.claim: “I know it's very controversial to say ‘stop and frisk.’ Okay? ‘Stop and frisk.’ You take guns away. Chicago is the greatest example I think I've ever seen of that.”
pageContext.analysis: Chicago experienced a surge in homicides the year after city police entered a consent decree with the federal government that imposed more recordkeeping and data collection requirements for the use of stop and frisk tactics. But the Justice Department and researchers from the University of Chicago say the consent decree, which did not end stop and frisk, was not established to be the cause of the homicide surge in 2016.
